identified-content.object.title: PERRY MASON (TV PROGRAM)
CASE OF THE RECKLESS ROMEO, THE (TV PROGRAM)

hedline.hl1: Reviews/Television; Geraldo Rivera as a Murder Victim on 'Perry Mason'

block.p: The tired but durable "Perry Mason" formula hits on an unusually tantalizing gimmick this evening: Geraldo Rivera as murder victim. Before thousands weep or cheer, let it be noted quickly that Mr. Rivera is not really the victim. He is merely playing the title role in "The Case of the Reckless Romeo," tonight at 8 on NBC. But the character's resemblance to Mr. Rivera in several respects stretches coincidence very near to the breaking point.

Ted, as he's called, is the host of "Revelations," a cable-television show specializing in tabloid sensationalism. "Watch yourself, because someone may be watching you," is Ted's warning to viewers. A familiar story: The show is sleaze, the ratings are climbing.

Ted, as he's called, is the host of "Revelations," a cable-television show specializing in tabloid sensationalism. "Watch yourself, because someone may be watching you," is Ted's warning to viewers. A familiar story: The show is sleaze, the ratings are climbing.

But Ted doesn't just expose the pecadillos of others. Now he's publishing a book about himself, complete with detailed descriptions and photos of a string of former lovers. As it happens, Mr. Rivera himself published just such a book not too long ago, and subsequently conceded that it was probably a mistake.
Most of Ted's kiss-and-tell victims are furious. "That S.O.B!" cries the producer, one of the betrayed. "Yes, but he's

S.O.B," counters the sponsor, who also happens to be Ted's current fiancee. An actress says her agent is always saying she should do something environmental. "Killing Ted," she decides, "would be right up there with saving the ozone layer." Offering a copy of the book to a female colleague, Ted is told: "Thanks, but I haven't finished reading 'Mein Kampf.' "

Ted wonders why people don't have a sense of humor. Everyone else suggests he get a bodyguard. Sure enough, Ted is found with a knife through his heart, reportedly killed by a woman in a red dress. Each of the many suspects, of course, owns a red dress, providing the properly colored herrings. The case proceeds to the courtroom, where Mr. Mason, as embalmed in the authoritative voice of Raymond Burr, gets down to business as usual.

But it's not quite the same without Mr. Rivera's unflaggingly cocky presence. He has been a natural before the camera from his very beginning on television, more than 20 years ago. He just has to be himself. As someone says of Ted's ability to insinuate himself, "Guess he was a very good actor." As for Mr. Rivera's motive in playing this reckless Romeo, you have a choice: Sense of humor, or no sense of shame. Perry Mason The Case of the Reckless Romeo Written by Brian Clemens. Christian I.
